title: Why do you think Admiral Byrd went to the South Pole? - Quora

response.answer_text: Which trip? He flew there a number of times, landed later in life, did work in other parts of the Antarctic. This was why he was made an Admiral. First, he was an explorer. That was in the final part of the major period of colonization/exploration of the USA. That’s when the US started establishing permanent bases in part for the Cold War and to show up even our WW2 and pre-WW1 Allies. He could not beat Amundsen or Scott (who stupidly and idealistically (be warned of idealists) died). He could not claim nor was able to landing at North Pole. It’s over water. Now some dispute Byrd flying over the N. Pole for various reasons. That’s not the official US position, but it’s not quite worth defending too much, because it’s water not land. When you think about how stupid some of the other countries have been about the Antarctic, establishing the South Pole Station and naming it after Amundsen and Scott was a brilliant stroke for the time (neither Americans). It was a period of land conquest. It was not a single event but a series of events staged over time for various world threats/competition. Why do you have to ask? Can I sell you a Bridge?

He did go to the South Pole in 1947 (same year as Roswell, New Mexico UFO incident), but only as a cover story to escape the mass media. He then flew his plane to the North Pole where he met the “Guardians of the Planet”, an advanced civilization of peoples within the center of the hollow earth, who told Byrd to tell the world to stop using Nuclear Atomic bombs or else we will destroy ourselves.
